results.title: Hymn for the Hurting
results.abstract: A new poem from Amanda Gorman, written after the tragedy in Uvalde, Texas.

results.adx_keywords: Reality Television;Home Repairs and Improvements;Real Estate and Housing (Residential);Suits and Litigation (Civil);HGTV
results.title: What Goes On Behind the Cameras at Home Makeover Shows?
results.abstract: Some homeowners said they were promised a dream house if a crew remade their homes for TV. The lawsuits they filed later told a different story.

media.caption: Paul and Mindy King went on Property Brothers in 2019. They are now suing Cineflix, the production company behind the program, saying that what they got was a house riddled with structural and electrical issues, some of which, they contend, are producing serious health concerns for Ms. King.
media.copyright: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times

results.title: America’s Human Sacrifices
results.abstract: Guns don’t kill people. Doors do.

media.caption: Gabriella Uriegas, a soccer teammate of Tess Mata, who died in the shooting, cried at a makeshift memorial outside the Uvalde County Courthouse on Thursday.

results.title: Deep in Vatican Archives, Scholar Discovers ‘Flabbergasting’ Secrets
results.abstract: David Kertzer has spent decades excavating the Vatican’s hidden history, with his work winning a Pulitzer and capturing Hollywood’s attention. A new book examines Pope Pius XII’s role in the Holocaust.

media.caption: David Kertzer at the library of the American Academy in Rome, after a day of scholarly investigations inside the Vatican’s archives.
media.copyright: Massimo Berruti for The New York Times

results.title: Testing Positive and Using the ‘Backdoor’ to Get Into the U.S.
results.abstract: Entering the United States by air requires a negative coronavirus test. Some people who can’t provide one are using a workaround: flying to Canada or Mexico, then entering via a land border.
org_facet: American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media.caption: Crossings at land borders, like this one at the Peace Bridge connecting Canada and the United States, do not require negative coronavirus tests.

results.title: An Irish National Treasure Gets Set for a Long-Needed Restoration

results.abstract: The housing market has altered the math of moving for nearly everyone.

results.title: How a 7,000-Ton Broadway Theater Was Hoisted 30 Feet
results.abstract: The Beaux-Arts interior of the Palace Theater is a protected landmark, so developers had to devise a plan to raise it three stories in their effort to add more retail space.

media.caption: The Palace Theater stage, in the process of being lifted, at TSX Broadway in New York, in 2020.

results.title: Dervla Murphy, Irish Travel Writer Who Preferred Her Bike, Dies at 90
results.abstract: A curious, intrepid loner, she famously went from Dunkirk through Europe and then to Iran, Afghanistan, Pakistan and India — mostly on two wheels.

media.caption: The Irish travel writer Dervla Murphy at her home in Lismore, County Waterford, in 2018.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Homosexuality and Bisexuality;Holocaust and the Nazi Era;World War II (1939-45);Concentration Camps;Jews and Judaism;Heuman, Margot (1928-2022)
results.title: Margot Heuman, Who Bore Witness to the Holocaust as a Gay Woman, Dies at 94
results.abstract: She was a rare survivor who spoke — in recent years — of her same-sex relationship in the concentration camps, and how it sustained her.

media.caption: Margot Heuman in 2019. “Because of my caring for another human being,” she said of her relationship with another woman during the Holocaust, “we somehow never lost our dignity and remained people.”

results.title: A Grilled Shrimp Feast, Best Enjoyed Outdoors

results.title: The Budding 19-Year-Old Star at the French Open Not Named Carlos Alcaraz
results.abstract: Holger Rune of Denmark is making his mark in Paris. His childhood rival is hogging the spotlight. That is just fine with him — for now.

media.caption: Holger Rune plays a game filled with finesse. He drifts across the court and never seems to expend more energy than what’s necessary.

results.title: Trump’s Primary Losses Puncture His Invincibility
results.abstract: With many of Donald J. Trump’s endorsed candidates falling to defeat in recent primaries, some Republicans see an opening for a post-Trump candidate in 2024.

results.adx_keywords: Uvalde, Tex, Shooting (May 24, 2022);Buffalo, NY, Shooting (May 14, 2022);Gun Control;Basketball;Baseball;Kerr, Steve;Golden State Warriors;New York Yankees;Tampa Bay Rays
results.title: The Week When Sports Would Not Let America Look Away
results.abstract: As their games continued in the wake of mass shootings in Buffalo and Uvalde, Texas, Golden State Coach Steve Kerr, the Yankees and the Tampa Bay Rays made powerful statements against gun violence.

media.caption: In a news conference on Tuesday, Steve Kerr, Golden State’s head coach, waved off basketball questions to plead for gun control legislation. “When are we going to do something?” he asked.
media.copyright: Scott Strazzante/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press

results.adx_keywords: Dinosaurs;Temperature;Paleontology;Anatomy and Physiology;Biology and Biochemistry;Endangered and Extinct Species;Pterosaurs;Fossils;Research;your-feed-science;your-feed-animals;Nature (Journal)
results.title: Dinosaurs Started Out Hot, Then Some of Them Turned Cold
results.abstract: Scientists directly measured the metabolic rate of extinct animals, which revealed that some giant dinosaurs became coldblooded.

media.caption: Scientists were surprised to find that dinosaurs, like Triceratops, had reduced their metabolisms over time, ending up at metabolic rates closer to those of modern reptiles.
